text:
Paddle boarding tour from Sorrento to Bagni Regina Giovanna
There‚Äôs one surefire way to escape the Amalfi Coast‚Äôs crowds: get on the water. With this small-group tour, you‚Äôll meet your guide, get acquainted with‚Ä¶ ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ñ‡•Ä your paddleboard, and head out on the crystal waters toward Punta del Capo. Once arrived, you‚Äôll beach your boards and either head to explore the Roman villa of Pollio Felice‚Äîwhich dates back 2,000 years‚Äîgo for a swim, or simply enjoy the exquisite, uncrowded views. Read more about Paddle boarding tour from Sorrento to Bagni Regina Giovanna - https://www.viator.com/tours/Sorrento/Paddle-boarding-tour-from-Sorrento-to-Bagni-Regina-Giovanna/d947-284551P1?pid=P00070587&mcid=42383&medium=link&medium_version=selector
comments: [{'username': 'Sophia Jensen', 'comment_text': "It's really great to be here. What's the weather like there lately?"}]

text:
This post is for whomever is in Italy right now.
Could you post pics of your train‚Äôs seats with the train line name and whether you used economy, business or first class?
I‚Äôm piggy backing from Mbell Arteaga‚Äôs‡§Ü‡§£‡§ñ‡•Ä post with her amazing pics of train station gates and monitors with instructions.
Looks like there are several train companies with different seating arrangements and if we had visuals of each one it would be of great help!

TIA if anyone cares and remembers to do this üòÉ

Pic of my search of all train lines in Italy. Which ones are the faves??
comments:
[{'username': 'Chiara Normanno', 'comment_text': "Uhm those aren't train lines specifically, those are stations, train routes and train types mixed. Do you need seating pics of Frecciarossa? Frecciaargento?
Regional trains? Frecciabianca?"}, {'username': 'Agnese Arn√≥ Ch-Ch', 'comment_text': 'In Italy there are two national train companies: Trenitalia, the public one, that runs several types of trains (Frecciarossa -the fastest- Frecciargento, Frecciabianca -slightly slower- generally referred as Le Frecce, Intercity, Regionale -slower but with more stops, so if you need to go to a smaller city you‚Äôll probably want one of them) or Italo, the private company (only fast trains named Italo, very few lines).
Then there are some small local trains like Malpensa express, Circumvesuviana
or small local companies like Trenord (only in Lombardia).'}, {'username': 'Jeanne Eliason', 'comment_text': 'Jeanne Eliason'}, {'username': 'Rhona OConnor', 'comment_text': "I don't know what train lines I traveled on, that was not an issue for me - just booked using Trainline app..... Booked day, time, destination, class and seat. All worked out well."}, {'username': 'Charlie Charnigo', 'comment_text': 'This will answer all your questions and even ones you haven‚Äôt thought of‚Ä¶

https://
www.seat61.com/'}, {'username': 'Rebecca Yeoh', 'comment_text': 'Trenitalia EuroCity Milan > Como, 1st business'}, {'username': 'Rebecca Yeoh', 'comment_text': 'Trenitalia Frecciarossa Milan > Rome, business (I was taking a photo of the barista machine)'}]

text:
I have planned strike questions. I hope someone who lives in Italy or has lived through strikes in Italy will have the answers!

I don't understand quite how they work. There are two planned strikes for when we will be in Italy. One is a rail strike that affects Italo, nation-wide. Naturally, we are scheduled to travel that day. The other is air traffic controllers, nation-wide.

The rail strike is scheduled for September 17-18, beginning at 3:00 AM on the 17th until 2:00 AM on the 18th, so 23 hours. We will be traveling at 8:30 AM on the 18th. Does this mean the trains will be backed up? How do we find out if our train will go that day at all if they are backed up?

The second strike is for what I think is air traffic controllers on September 16 from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM, although I don't think this one will affect us (but not positive) as we land at 11:30 AM on September 17. In this case, do planes just not take off from or for Italy that would be landing during the time period of the strike since there is no traffic control? I'll assume it will back up traffic for a day or two?

We don't typically experience this level of strikes in the US with such regularity, so I'm not sure of how stikes like these work or affect travel, locally and nationally. BTW, there are a LOT of planned strikes for local transportation all over Italy for September. You may want to check the strike calendar, just be sure you have Google translate on so you can read it properly--put in dates that would affect you. I'll add the link: https://www.commissionegaranziasciopero.it/calendario-scioperi?page=0
comments: [{'username': 'Vickie Love Hooper', 'comment_text': 'When we were there in July, there was a rail strike. We were trying to get from Venice to Trieste- we were told the strike would end at 3pm. It did, exactly at 3. I bought tickets to leave at 3:15 I believe and we left right on time. I‚Äôm guessing all the people with tickets exchanged them for a later time a lot.'}, {'username': 'Jo√´lle Simard', 'comment_text': 'I follow this publication to get the answers, because I will also be traveling on these dates'}, {'username': 'JoJo Sisto', 'comment_text': 'Following as we are planning to leave Rome on the 17th am to Naples and already have tickets booked ugh'}, {'username': 'Kathi Rose', 'comment_text': 'Does anyone know about a train strike Sept 15 - Rome to Bari?'}]

text: First time traveling to Italy next month. What are things you have to declare at customs? I use nicotine pouches. Is that something I'd have to declare
comments: [{'username': 'Jaime Cleek', 'comment_text': 'I think it‚Äôs only on your way out. We flew from Boston to Dublin to Naples and didn‚Äôt talk to a single person'}, {'username': 'Sandy Radican Shikaly', 'comment_text': 'If you are arriving from the United States.. say in Rome.. you will go through passport control/\nimmigration.. retrieve your luggage.. then customs which will be a walk through lane " nothing to declare" since you are just arriving there with no purchases to declare... when returning home if you made purchases in Italy you will declare them in the United States.'}, {'username': 'John Layman', 'comment_text': 'No problems with bringing smokeless tobacco.You better bring it,not sold in Italy'}]

text: Hello! I have never been to Italy before but I‚Äôm trying to plan a surprise trip for my partners birthday! I have lots of questions haha I‚Äôm thinking 4/5 days, I think there‚Äôs more that interest us in Rome but also want to go Venice to go on a gondola, is it possible to do a couple days in each? Can anyone recommend a nice hotel in the city centre of either? And any things that are a must see/do in either of these places? Thank you ‚ò∫Ô∏è
comments:
[{'username': 'Valentina Bachi', 'comment_text': 'From Roma you can easily take a fast train to Venice, but with 4/5 days only I would not advice you to do both.'}, {'username': 'Dann Hrusch', 'comment_text': "Three nights Rome and two in Venice would be enough to see major sites and have some great memories. That said, you're biggest expense will be airfare, so if you're already paying that, then consider adding a couple of days to spend more time in either city or add Florence."}, {'username': 'Ana Ka', 'comment_text': 'I would do only one place like Valentina suggested'}, {'username': 'Ana Ka', 'comment_text': 'I did that too for my parents long time ago üôÇ. They visited Rome and Florence‚Ä¶ was amazing trip they say.'}, {'username': 'Shirley Lewis', 'comment_text': 'do one city only in your 4/5 days ...'}, {'username': 'Julchen Zamora', 'comment_text': 'If you are planning a ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù be aware that this is a public group, meaning even if your partner is not part of this group if he/she has Facebook she/he could see it'}, {'username': 'Pam Kimak', 'comment_text': "Take a few more days..traveling
takes up 2 days. I recently went and was counting on flights being ontime..it just doesn't happen that often. The plan was to arrive at 8 a.m. and flight was delayed almost 4 hrs...half flights were canceled that day so we were lucky to take off at all. So we really only had half a day on our first day. Coming home,more hourly delays and then returning to ewr had to stand on line 40 minutes to show our passports to get back into U.S.. So my advice is, don't play it too close with your scheduling."}, {'username': 'Julie Koziol', 'comment_text': 'There is so much to see in Rome. I‚Äôve done a lot of research on things to do and places to go. I‚Äôm going with a tour group that‚Äôs doing Italy in 14 days. They are only spending one day in Rome. They are doing the Sistine chapel, Vatican museums, St Peter‚Äôs, the Colosseum and the Roman Forman. One day is not enough. So, I‚Äôm going 5 days early. I‚Äôm going to do the Hop on Hop off bus for 3 days and 1 evening. I‚Äôm going to download Rick Steves free audio tours. I‚Äôm also going to do a nighttime food golf cart tour. They have scooter tours, tipsy tours and shopping tours. Just look on FB. Plus, I plan on doing a lot of walking to just explore.'}, {'username': 'Bill Gillespie', 'comment_text': "Many rooms to choose close to Pantheon, it's centered between Piazza Novella, the Vatican, St. Peters, the Colloseum, Trevi and the Spanish steps. You'll be very very busy in Rome, would normally recommend at least 5 nights in Rome, in your case, 3 and 2."}, {'username': 'Jeff McLellan', 'comment_text': 'I know time and budget may be limited but if you are traveling from US or Canada I honestly could not image going to Italy for the first time for only 4/5 days especially trying to do more than one city. I would never do it if your flight was not direct either, we have delays both ways.'}, {'username': 'Sara Burrow', 'comment_text': '4/5 days is not enough to see Rome & Venice as Venice is in the North part of Italy & Rome in the South. You will spend too many hours traveling. I would save Venice for a future trip & visit Rome with a day trip to Amalfi Coast, a day in Rome, & then go to Florence.'}, {'username': 'Vinayini Murty', 'comment_text': 'And remember you will both have jetlag! That made our schedule wonky for a few days. I came from Canada. I agree with those who recommend a longer trip, particularly given the cost of airfare. Of you only have 4-5 days pick another place closer to your home...'}, {'username': 'Lucrezia Folger', 'comment_text': "4-5 days, plenty to do in Rome. The gondola will always be there as it's a tourist thing."}, {'username': 'Barbara Bastianini', 'comment_text': 'Everyone‚Äôs different but with only 4 or 5 days I‚Äôd spend the whole time in Rome.'}, {'username': 'Sara Butcher', 'comment_text': 'You can catch the fast train from Rome to Venice. You can definitely see a lot of both cites in that time. My favourite of the two is Venice. I normally get a train around 9-10am to go to the next city. That way I get up, have breakfast and go to station. You won‚Äôt get caught up somewhere and risk not making your train.
In Venice last trip, I stayed at Splendid Venice StarHotel. It‚Äôs 2 mins behind St Mark‚Äôs and is on a canal to make arrival/
departing via water taxi easy. Definitely consider water taxi for arrival, nothing more stunning! ‚ù§Ô∏èüá¶üá∫'}, {'username': 'Rebecca Yeoh', 'comment_text': 'For Rome, stay in the areas of Pantheon / Piazza Navona /
Campo de‚Äô Fiori ‚Äì best for first time visitors. Easily walk to major sights of the city and enjoy the atmosphere of one of the greatest cities on earth! If you need a hotel recommendation‚Ä¶Ho
tel Smeraldo üëåüèº https://
www.smeraldoroma
.com/en/'}, {'username': 'Jenny Frank', 'comment_text': 'Venice and Rome are 4 hours apart .'}, {'username': 'Karen Curci', 'comment_text': 'Our favorite hotel in Rome is Mecenate Palace. Within walking distance of the train station, which you can get to with the train from the airport. The hotel is right across from Santa Maria Maggiore.'}]

text: Buongiorno a tutti. I am looking for some recommendations/advice. I am planning on going to visit family in Asiago, Italy in late November/early December. The closest airports to Asiago are Bologna, Verona, Venice or Milan. We are not planning on renting a car and will be travelling by train or bus from the airport to Asiago. I am looking for suggestions as to which is the best route to Asiago, that has some nice points of interest to stop along the way, between the airport we land in and Asiago. Thanks for your time.
comments:
[{'username': 'Suzanne Joslin Oliveria', 'comment_text': 'Check rome to Rio app from all those cities. It will show all.of your options'}, {'username': 'Fetchin Gretchen', 'comment_text': 'The best route to Asiago from the four airports you mentioned depends on your interests and budget. Here are a few options:

Bologna: This is the closest airport to Asiago, and it is also the most affordable option. You can take a train from Bologna Centrale station to Asiago. The journey takes about 2 hours.

Verona: This airport is a bit further from Asiago than Bologna, but it has more flight options. You can take a train from Verona Porta Nuova station to Asiago. The journey takes about 2.5 hours.

Venice: This airport is the furthest from Asiago, but it is also the most popular tourist destination in Italy. You can take a train from Venice Santa Lucia station to Asiago. The journey takes about 3 hours.

Milan: This airport is also a popular tourist destination, but it is not as close to Asiago as Bologna or Verona. You can take a train from Milan Centrale station to Asiago. The journey takes about 3.5 hours.

If you are looking for a route with some nice points of interest to stop along the way, I would recommend flying into Bologna and taking the train to Asiago. You can stop in the town of Vicenza, which is known for its beautiful architecture.

You can also stop in the town of Marostica, which is known for its annual chess tournament that is played in the streets.

If you are flying into Verona, you can stop in the town of Verona, which is home to the famous Verona Arena.

If you are flying into Venice, you can stop in the city of Venice itself, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.'}]

text:
So.. have been planning my dream Italian trip for months . 8 months to be exact. I always wanted to go to Italy. I was so looking forward to going to this country with my two kids and husband .

We were all ready , packed and with only 4 hours left for the flight my son started having severe stomach pain. Rushed him to the ER , he had to have appendix surgery and we came home 2 days later .
Missed the flight , all but one airbnbs returned 50% . All of the attraction tickets I bought through official websites do not have any cancellation option so I will have to start calling them tomorrow . Only cancellation that happened was via Viator .
I don‚Äôt know how to feel. I am extremely relieved that my son didn‚Äôt get sick in the air or in Italy but I am so extremely lost now with what to do next.
Bought my plane tickets through a third party and they are of no help when I tried to reschedule. I am constantly on the phone . As of now they are saying don‚Äôt be hopeful on the air ticket refund. I will keep trying .
Had so much fun planning this trip.. this group was nothing but wonderful. Just wanted to share my story here .please keep my family in your prayers .
comments:
[{'username': 'Nansi Foster', 'comment_text': 'Glad your son is doing well and that is the most important. Good luck with the rest of your problems about refund your money üò¢ hope you had a plan to be fully refunded everything, because it is going to be hard. üôè‚ù§Ô∏è unfortunately some companies they don‚Äôt really care about us but only for the profit if you don‚Äôt have a plan to get back your money say good bye to them.. üòå I‚Äôm sorry üòû but think positive your son is doing well!! üôèüòä'}, {'username': 'Sheryl Vasconcelos', 'comment_text': 'Glad your son is ok.
Hope you can go to Italy another time.'}, {'username': 'Lucy Thornton', 'comment_text': "Hope your son is ok, but don't let them away with charging you, did you have free cancellation on your properties booked? Flights through a third party are notorious, hope your son is OK and I hope you had insurance x"}, {'username': 'Gina Winterstein', 'comment_text': 'Did you have travel insurance?'}, {'username': 'Helen Layton Brechler', 'comment_text': 'Deny the charges'}, {'username': 'Sally Staltare', 'comment_text': 'Hopefully you will get all your monies back
Thank God your Son is ok ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏èüôèüèºüôèüèº'}, {'username': 'Jenny Kendrick', 'comment_text': 'So sorry to hear your going through this.'}, {'username': 'Christine Alesia', 'comment_text': 'I‚Äôm so sorry this happened, but thankfully it didn‚Äôt happen while overseas. I‚Äôm so glad he is ok.
Good luck trying to reschedule, how awful to lose all that money. Hopefully some let you pick new dates.'}, {'username': 'Lynn Alsandor', 'comment_text': 'We were in the same boat when a hurricane hit our home town. Hours of phone calls and never was fully reimbursed. I will never not go through a travel agent or not have insurance. So glad your son is ok.'}, {'username': 'Ruth Dias', 'comment_text': 'üò™ü§ïüôè‚ù§'}, {'username': 'Alicia Cox', 'comment_text': 'So sorry, but glad your son is ok. That could have ended really badly. Maybe get a copy of the hospital bill & that will give you some additional credibility with some of these vendors to get your money back. Good luck!'}, {'username': 'Ramona Rodriguez', 'comment_text': 'üôèüèΩ'}, {'username': 'Silvia Arndt', 'comment_text': 'I feel as if everything happens for a reason..now was not the time to go to Italy. You and your family will get there and have an amazing time ‚ù§Ô∏è'}, {'username': 'Rosanna Hardeman', 'comment_text': 'Be thankful that you weren‚Äôt in flight and had his appendix rupture.

Hopefully, you can rebook and enjoy your trip at a later date.'}, {'username': 'Linda San Paolo', 'comment_text': 'Wish you the best in recovering and refunded..... this happened to me and alot of people during COVID-19 I was very lucky that I could rebook....hang in there and I hope you get a fair deal!'}, {'username': 'Nana-nomie Morales', 'comment_text': 'I‚Äôm so sorry this happened to you, but more importantly your son is ok, healthy and full of life ‚ù§Ô∏è I hope and pray you make it to Italy one day üëèüèº
We are planning on going in 2025 with family and friends
I wish your family the best ‚ù§Ô∏èüôèüèº'}, {'username': 'Debbie Jones Schilling', 'comment_text': 'Praying you get your money back and you get to Italy one day. That would be super disappointing. My heart goes out to you. Glad you‚Äôre son is well.'}, {'username': 'Kathleen Chaudhari', 'comment_text': 'My family of 6 had to cancel 2 trips to Alaska, once in 2020 because of covid and then in 2021 when my sister unexpectedly passed away. Both times we rescheduled everything for the very next year. I was shocked how many Airbnb‚Äôs allowed us to transfer our reservations. Tour companies, too. Email them about your sons hospitalization
and ask them for some grace ‚Äî even those with a ‚Äúno refund‚Äù policy did allow us to transfer. Good luck!'}, {'username': 'Peter Nagafuchi', 'comment_text': 'It‚Äôs only money Your son is alive and well. You are very fortunate to have dodged a bullet. Italy will always be there.'}, {'username': 'Ruth Francis', 'comment_text': 'So sorry for you. I hope you had travel insurance..!!'}, {'username': 'Sarah Rogers Zakala', 'comment_text': 'I‚Äôm so sorry to hear this happened. I am sending good thoughts to you that all the things you have to do to cancel go as smoothly as possible.'}, {'username': 'Kerry Jacobsen', 'comment_text': 'I am so sad to read what happened. I wish there was something I could say to help. I can‚Äôt imagine how disappointing this would be. I hope that knowing so many people care brings you some comfort.'}, {'username': 'Rosslyn Patience', 'comment_text': 'Travel insurance is a must. I hope everything Is alright now and your son is better. It would have been a nightmare experience.'}, {'username': 'Sandra Keyser', 'comment_text': 'So very sorry ü´Ç'}, {'username': 'Tamala Mallett Moore', 'comment_text': 'üôèüèæüôèüèæüôèüèæ'}, {'username': 'Donna Cafora Shepard', 'comment_text': 'I‚Äôm so sorry that happened to you. Always get travel insurance! You never know what will happen. The night before we were scheduled to come home, my son got the flu and had a fever of 104. There was no way he was getting on a plane. We took him to a hospital and they said he couldn‚Äôt fly for five days. There was no charge at the hospital and they gave us a note that he couldn‚Äôt fly. I called the airlines right away to cancel our flight and see if they could get us on another one. The trouble was it was the week between Christmas and New Years and all the planes were full! Finally they got us on one New Years Eve but had to bump us up to business class because all the other seats were filled. When I got home I contacted our travel insurance company and they were great! They covered the balance on our airfare and even asked if I had receipts for the extra nights for rooms and food! We stayed with friends so we didn‚Äôt have any extra expenses but they were ready to cover those too!'}, {'username': 'Lynne Roy', 'comment_text': 'While you may not get a refund, you may get credit to use your tickets to book a different trip. The typical caveat is you need to travel before the 12 month expires - and often the 12 months is from when you made the original reservations - not the departure date.'}, {'username': 'Kay Lennington', 'comment_text': "I can imagine how disappointed you are and yet grateful at the same time. I hope you're able to go soon."}, {'username': 'Norma Marr', 'comment_text': 'I‚Äôm so sorry. This happened to us in 2020. We planned an Italian trip and cruise. Sixteen day trip. We couldn‚Äôt go due to Covid and I have poor immunity. You should be able to get refunds from everyone you booked with, with just a letter from your sons dr. That‚Äôs how we did it. I hope it works for you. Good luck. üëç'}, {'username': 'Leslie Goodland', 'comment_text': "God had that happen for a reason. That's how you have to look at it."}, {'username': 'Kathryn Zurcher-Baglien', 'comment_text': "Ohhhh what a sad turn of events! Glad your son is better but don't give up on the Italy dream. Make sure you provide documentation on the emergency surgery and hopefully that will help recoup some of the cost."}, {'username': 'Wendy Morelli', 'comment_text': 'So sorry ‚Ä¶..but hope you will get your dream trip soon! ü•∞ü•∞ü•∞üôèüôèüôèüëçüëçüëç'}, {'username': 'Barbara Bastianini', 'comment_text': 'I‚Äôm so sorry this happened to you. I can imagine how disappointed you are.

But as someone who was involved in a life threatening accident in Rome that required hospitalization
and surgery I have to say I‚Äôm glad his problem
happened here instead of in Italy. To be honest, I received excellent medical care there and they saved my life. But it‚Äôs very frightening and psychologically
difficult to deal with a medical system you‚Äôre unfamiliar with. And where you maybe aren‚Äôt fluent with the language. (I can say some common phrases in Italian but medical terms were beyond me.). Then there‚Äôs the financial aspect. Before leaving the first hospital I had to pay 24 thousand Euros for my stay of three days plus surgery. The second hospitalization
which lasted two full weeks was additional. I can‚Äôt even begin to tell you how stressful it would have been to face those worries in a foreign country on top of concerns for your sons health.

On the bright side, as I said before, I was treated very well by the doctors and hospital staff. All of my hotels were extremely cooperative and refunded my non refundable payments in full. I hadn‚Äôt expected that but was certainly happy they did it. I had purchased flight insurance which covered my missed flight back home. I was also lucky in that my home medical insurance reimbursed me in full for the amount I had to pay the Italian hospitals. And my insurance also paid for a first class flight ticket to get me home as well as paid for a nurse to accompany me.

So although you were unlucky with what happened, in another way you were lucky it happened before your trip not while you were on it.

Here‚Äôs what I learned from my own experience.
1. Buy medical insurance for each trip. Most US policies do not provide for the reimbursement mine did. But you do need to have coverage while abroad.
2. Buy flight insurance. It‚Äôs cheap
but so important if something happens.
3. Be sure any insurance you have provides for evacuation home.
4. Always book directly with the provider (the airline or the hotel itself, for example) because the third party is just another layer of bureaucracy you have to deal with if something goes wrong.
5. Stay in a fully staffed hotel not a vacation rental. The help provided by the hotel staff was invaluable to me. From going with me in an ambulance, to making arrangements to extend my husband‚Äôs longer than intended stay at reduced rates, to making phone calls for us I honestly can‚Äôt imagine how we‚Äôd have navigated the situation without their kindness and help. They did so many things, both little and big, to help
us out during our nightmare. I‚Äôll be forever grateful to all of them.
6. Take along an extra high limit credit card to be used only in case of an emergency.

None of this will help you right now. But I wanted you to know you‚Äôre not alone in having had a trip ruined by medical issues. I‚Äôm proof that anything can happen so I hope passing on what I learned might somehow help to prevent struggles in the future.

And of course, I hope your son is fine and healthy now. That‚Äôs really the most important thing.'}, {'username': 'Genevieve Hunt', 'comment_text': 'I‚Äôm so sorry for this. Such a huge disappointment.'}, {'username': 'Bea Kuckens', 'comment_text': 'Next time get travel insurance.'}, {'username': 'Carolyn Adams Brown', 'comment_text': 'I am sure you are very disappointed. We had planned a trip to Rome, Venice and Paris prior to Covid. I spent a year planning it and had to cancel everything. Plane and train tickets, tours, lodings etc. I really feel your pain. text: Staying two nights in Rome, post cruise in early Nov. Looking at reasonably priced hotel options with access to public transportation, since we will not have a car. Is it still too crowded near Trevi fountain to stay in a hotel near there that time of year? Also, Queen and king size beds seem non-existent in Rome and maybe Europe in general. Is that a fair assessment?

Ive stayed many times, very close to Termini station, very clean, and queen beds!'}, {'username': 'Ishbel Raffle', 'comment_text': 'Rooms are small in city centre hotels in Europe - hence small beds. If you‚Äôre happy to take public transport perhaps hotels on the outskirts will offer larger rooms/beds'}, {'username': 'Mandy Pusateri', 'comment_text': 'We are staying three days in Rome before a cruise and found a great AirBnB.'}, {'username': 'Tracy Wrinn Mcdermott', 'comment_text': 'In my experience a ‚Äúdouble‚Äù in Europe is often two singles(twins) put together or closer to a queen size. They are larger than a typical American ‚Äúdouble/full‚Äù sized bed.'}, {'username': 'Fetchin Gretchen', 'comment_text': 'Yes, it is still too crowded near the Trevi Fountain to stay in a hotel near there in early November. The fountain is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Rome, and it is always crowded, even in the off-season. If you are looking for a reasonably priced hotel with access to public transportation,
I would recommend staying in a hotel in a less crowded area, such as Trastevere or the Monti neighborhood.

And also yes, queen and king size beds are not as common in Europe as they are in the United States. The standard bed size in Europe is a double bed, which is about the size of a twin bed in the United States. However, there are some hotels that do offer queen and king size beds, but they may be more expensive.

Here are some reasonably priced hotels in Rome with access to public transportation:

Hotel Forum: This hotel is located in the historic center of Rome, near the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. It has a metro station right outside the door, making it easy to get around the city. The hotel has a variety of room sizes, including double, twin, and family rooms.

Hotel Raphael: This hotel is located in the Monti neighborhood, a short walk from the Trevi Fountain and the Spanish Steps. It has a bus stop right in front of the hotel, making it easy to get around the city. The hotel has a variety of room sizes, including double, twin, and family rooms.

Hotel Santa Maria: This hotel is located in the Trastevere neighborhood, a lively and charming neighborhood with a lot of restaurants and bars. It has a metro station within walking distance, making it easy to get around the city. The hotel has a variety of room sizes, including double, twin, and family rooms.

I hope this helps!'}]

text: Hi, I'm after recommendations of the best area of Italy to go for tours/accommodation that focuses on the slow food movement and organic food - even cooking classes that you gather your own ingredients and then cook etc. Even better if anyone can recommend somewhere near Amalfi Coast/Sorrento or near Florance? Thanks
comments: [{'username': 'Rob Pek Proietti', 'comment_text': 'Tuscany is the best region IMO. Food, landscape, wine, islands, etc... I lived in California for many years and helped lots of people planning their dream tour of Tuscany. Now I moved back to Italy. How many days? My main recommendation is not trying to visit as many places as possible... you can only see/enjoy a handful of places in one or two weeks.. then of course each person has is own interests and travel style so, depending on your budget and number of travelers, I would suggest to contact someone that does custom tours for small groups.'}]

text: Thanks for the add, all! I‚Äôm planning my first trip to Italy in October! We can only go for 7 days üò¢. We (my 27 year old son and I) will be based in Bologna and are planning 3-4 day trips by train. Where are the ‚Äúmust go‚Äù cities y‚Äôall recommend?
comments:
[{'username': 'Diane Davis Lawyer', 'comment_text': "That's a very subjection question, depending on what your likes are personally. We are going to Florence, Rome, and Amalfi region. We fly into and out of Naples. If you're a museum and art person, then Florence. If you like architecture and ancient history, Rome. If you're going for the sea and scenery Amalfi or Cinque Terre. If you love rolling hills and beautiful landscapes, Tuscany. Honestly, can't see how you can go wrong in Italy. I've not seen any pictures on this group from anywhere in all of Italy that haven't been breathtaking. Enjoy! Good luck!"}, {'username': 'Nadia Waugh', 'comment_text': "You're very well situated to visit Venice and Florence, but also, take advantage of the region you're in: if you're a foodie, Modena and Parma are easy to get to, and on the coast you have Ravenna as well...have a great trip!"}, {'username': 'Valentina Bachi', 'comment_text': 'From Bologna with fast train you can easily go to Florence, Venice, Milano, and Rome. South of Italy would be a bit distant.'}, {'username': 'Ana Ka', 'comment_text': 'I would be careful with Parma though. Had a bad incident some years back (we were almost attacked by a group of 10 youngsters ) and recenmy friends car was mugged there (glass broken, things stolen). But all the other towns mentioned are amazing üôÇ'}, {'username': 'Beth Ann', 'comment_text': 'Florence, Venice, Verona, Padova, and you could try also to get to the Southern parts of Lake Garda like Sirmione - you are well situated to see all those cities and also to enjoy Bologna which is a great city!'}, {'username': 'Laura Piccinini', 'comment_text': 'Modena, food and motors, UNESCO site.
Also seaside for food and stroll (Rimini or Riccione)'}, {'username': 'Rhona OConnor', 'comment_text': 'The Lamborgini factory and museum might interest him. 40 mins on the bus from Bologna.'}, {'username': 'Rhona OConnor', 'comment_text': 'Rhona OConnor'}, {'username': 'Gianna Onesi', 'comment_text': "It's a good area you can get to Florence by train, Lucca, Pisa"}, {'username': 'Debra Abrams', 'comment_text': 'Thanks for all the great comments! We chose Bologna because it‚Äôs so centrally located and easy to get to other cities, but we have such a limited amount of time, so the real question is, WHERE should we go? We are not as much into churches and historical sights as we are foodies and would love to shop and explore quaint neighborhoods. So if you only had a handful of days to travel from Bologna, where would you absolutely want to go?'}, {'username': 'Fetchin Gretchen', 'comment_text': 'That sounds like a great trip! Here are a few "must go" cities in Italy that are a short train ride from Bologna:

* **Florence:** The capital of the Tuscany region, Florence is home to the world-famous Uffizi Gallery and the Accademia Gallery, where you can see Michelangelo's David. Florence is also a great city for wandering around and exploring the narrow streets and alleyways.
[Image of Florence, Italy]
[Image of Uffizi Gallery, Florence, Italy]
* **Siena:** This beautiful medieval city is known for its Piazza del Campo, a large square with a shell-shaped fountain. Siena is also home to the Leaning Tower of San Gimignano, a 14th-century tower that is one of the most iconic landmarks in Italy.
* **Pisa:** This city is home to the Leaning Tower of Pisa, which is one of the most recognizable landmarks in the world. Pisa is also a great place to visit if you are interested in history and architecture.
* **Modena:** This city is known for its balsamic vinegar and its Ferrari museum. Modena is also a great place to visit if you are interested in food and wine.

If you are interested in art and history, I would recommend visiting Florence and Siena. If you are interested in food and wine, I would recommend visiting Modena. And if you are interested in seeing a unique landmark, I would recommend visiting Pisa.

No matter which cities you choose to visit, you are sure to have a great time in Italy!'}, {'username': 'Lucrezia Folger', 'comment_text': 'In 7 days, (not arriving and departing as part of those days) Bologna and 1 other place.'}, {'username': 'Catherine AleXandra', 'comment_text': 'Just did Bologna as my epicenter. Train to Florence soooo fast! High Speed train. Super flexible. Easy tickets. Can always catch the next one.

Bologna is perfect! Omg it‚Äôs so much cheaper compared to other cities. So laid back. Best food. You will love it!!! I‚Äôm excited for you.

You could go to Florence in less time than it takes for most people to commute to work.
A fast 40 minutes.

The Florence station connects to the bus terminal. From there you can go anywhere in Tuscany.

Venice 1.5 hours. Stay overnight and see San Marco square at night.'}]
